subject: PLDM: implement surveillance between Host and bmc
commitMessage:
PLDM: implement surveillance between Host and bmc

This commit is to implement surveillance between host
and bmc, wherein host monitors if bmc is up and
running through constant pings(by sending Platform
EventMessages) sent from host to BMC. And if BMC
fails to respond to the pings, then BMC will be
reset using the KCS interface.

1. Host->BMC - GetTID
2. BMC->Host - Respond to GetTID, SetEventReceiver
3. Host->BMC - Respond to SetEventReceiver
4. BMC->Host -  Send PlatformEventMessage after the
   elapsed time interval(specified with
   SetEventReceiver command)
4. Host->BMC - If BMC fails to send respond to host
   within specified interval, Host resets BMC via
   the KCS interface

Tested with PLDMTOOL:
SetEventReceiver command:
root@rain127bmc:/tmp# ./pldmtool base GetTID -m 8
Received Msg
08 01 81 00 02
Sending Msg
01 00 02 00 01
{
    "Response": 1
}

platformEventMessage command(which will be received
by host):
root@rain118bmc:/tmp# ./pldmtool raw -d 0x80 0x02
0x0A 0x01 0x01 0x06 0x01 0x01
Request Message:
08 01 80 02 0a 01 01 06 01 01
Received Msg
08 01 80 02 0a 01 01 06 01 01
eventClass Checking
Sending Msg
00 02 0a 00 00
Response Message:
08 01 00 02 0a 00 00
Received Msg
08 01 00 02 0a 00 00

Signed-off-by: Sagar Srinivas <sagar.srinivas@ibm.com>
Change-Id: Iac90b2233a873a54504ffa649d324d30525b7ce3

Done
would this be a configurable option ? so that client that want a bigger time interval can increase it ?
Sending a setEventReceiver command after we get GetTID -  is this a generic thing that all companies would do ?
magic number
blocking call ? we should go with async direction right ?
that will be followed in a separate commit
magic value , this should ideally be configured via meta-layer if you are placing this code generic for every one.
moved this constant to meson options

bmc will respond to the GetTID command from host, and then immediately send a setEventReceiver command right. as - written it looks like we dont respond to GetTID command and instead send a SetEventReceiver command.
Ack
magic number ?
Done
Is this going to be watchdog with hostboot? Will there be surveillance with PHYP as well?
This commit is as part of surveillance, commits for watchdog with HostBoot is in following commits in the chain

As per DSP0248_1.2.0 iirc there can be only one Event Receiver in the platform subsystem, on OpenBMC Host/BMC communication has taken an exception to that and PlatformEventMessage flows in both directions. Apart from that the flow looks good.
Ack

The commit message can be improved for reviewers understanding by providing different steps involved.

1. Host->BMC - GetTID
2. BMC->Host - SetEventReceiver
3. .. and so on
Done
by
Done
i guess there will be a follow up commit to make the command async
+1, the registerRequest API can be leveraged for that.
Done
if (rc || completionCode)
Done
unsigned
Done

There is an imperfection in sending SetEventReceiver in the responseHandler of GetTID. Ideally sending SetEventReceiver as a response for GetTID should be done in the context of the InitializationAgent. GetTID is a command that could be invoked otherwise as well, in which case SetEventReceiver should not be sent. Till we have a full fledged InitializationAgent we can probably live with this. Other maintainers can also share their views.
Since we do not have an initialization agent in plan, we leveraged getTID to start off the surveillance. we can look back at this approach once the initialization agent is is in place
Defer is typically used when there are long running actions which we want to separate. In this case sending the request for SetEventReceiver which can be done in the ResponseHandler.

the setEventReceiver is deferred here not because of long running action but due to the fact that bmc needs to respond to getTID first and then send a setEventReceiver request. the Host does not run async and expects response to it's own command first
C++20 introduces std::bind_front, mem_fn might not be needed.
Done
Define a fixture class for the initialization common to base commands
Done
A more generic help text.
Done
may be a better string here indicating the actual failure. you can do that when addressing other's review comments
it would be good to explain what is surveillance as well
Done
how does this happen ? it is better to add that as well in the commit message .
@Manoj what specific information would be required to mention here?
Done
this will clutter the bmc journal
Ack
